subject: Data
title: Sensational Headlines and Buried Context
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Sensational Headlines and Buried Context.

hook.text: Headline: 'Coffee Causes Cancer!' Paragraph 12: 'In rats. At doses equivalent to 100 cups per day.'

buildup.text: News headlines optimize for clicks, not accuracy. Important context is often buried deep in the article.

discovery.text: Most people read only headlines. The gap between headline and reality is where misinformation lives.

twist.text: Even quality newspapers write misleading headlines â€” because editors, not scientists, write them.

climax.text: Reading past the headline is the simplest, most effective data literacy skill you can practice.

punchline.text: The headline is the ad. The article is the product.

quiz.question: Why are news headlines about data often misleading?
options: Headlines optimize for clicks, burying context deep in the article
